Fashion it thus; that what he is, augmented,
Would run to these and these extremities:
And therefore think him as a serpent's egg
Which, hatch'd, would, as his kind, grow mischievous,
And kill him in the shell.

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: The taper burneth in your closet, sir.
Searching the window for a flint, I found
This paper, thus seal'd up; and, I am sure,
It did not lie there when I went to bed.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Get you to bed again; it is not day.
Is not to-morrow, boy, the ides of March?

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: I know not, sir.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Look in the calendar, and bring me word.

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: I will, sir.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: The exhalations whizzing in the air
Give so much light that I may read by them.
'Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake, and see thyself.
Shall Rome, &c. Speak, strike, redress!
Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake!'
Such instigations have been often dropp'd
Where I have took them up.
'Shall Rome, &c.' Thus must I piece it out:
Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome?
My ancestors did from the streets of Rome
The Tarquin drive, when he was call'd a king.
'Speak, strike, redress!' Am I entreated
To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise:
If the redress will follow, thou receivest
Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus!

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: Sir, March is wasted fourteen days.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: 'Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks.
Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,
I have not slept.
Between the acting of a dreadful thing
And the first motion, all the interim is
Like a phantasma, or a hideous dream:
The Genius and the mortal instruments
Are then in council; and the state of man,
Like to a little kingdom, suffers then
The nature of an insurrection.

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door,
Who doth desire to see you.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Is he alone?

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: No, sir, there are moe with him.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Do you know them?

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: No, sir; their hats are pluck'd about their ears,
And half their faces buried in their cloaks,
That by no means I may discover them
By any mark of favour.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Let 'em enter.
They are the faction. O conspiracy,
Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night,
When evils are most free? O, then by day
Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough
To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy;
Hide it in smiles and affability:
For if thou path, thy native semblance on,
Not Erebus itself were dim enough
To hide thee from prevention.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: I think we are too bold upon your rest:
Good morrow, Brutus; do we trouble you?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: I have been up this hour, awake all night.
Know I these men that come along with you?

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Yes, every man of them, and no man here
But honours you; and every one doth wish
You had but that opinion of yourself
Which every noble Roman bears of you.
This is Trebonius.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: He is welcome hither.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: This, Decius Brutus.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: He is welcome too.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: They are all welcome.
What watchful cares do interpose themselves
Betwixt your eyes and night?

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Shall I entreat a word?

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Here lies the east: doth not the day break here?

speeches.speaker: CASCA
lines: No.

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: O, pardon, sir, it doth; and yon gray lines
That fret the clouds are messengers of day.

speeches.speaker: CASCA
lines: You shall confess that you are both deceived.
Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises,
Which is a great way growing on the south,
Weighing the youthful season of the year.
Some two months hence up higher toward the north
He first presents his fire; and the high east
Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Give me your hands all over, one by one.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: And let us swear our resolution.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: No, not an oath: if not the face of men,
The sufferance of our souls, the time's abuse,--
If these be motives weak, break off betimes,
And every man hence to his idle bed;
So let high-sighted tyranny range on,
Till each man drop by lottery. But if these,
As I am sure they do, bear fire enough
To kindle cowards and to steel with valour
The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen,
What need we any spur but our own cause,
To prick us to redress? what other bond
Than secret Romans, that have spoke the word,
And will not palter? and what other oath
Than honesty to honesty engaged,
That this shall be, or we will fall for it?
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,
Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls
That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear
Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain
The even virtue of our enterprise,
Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits,
To think that or our cause or our performance
Did need an oath; when every drop of blood
That every Roman bears, and nobly bears,
Is guilty of a several bastardy,
If he do break the smallest particle
Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: But what of Cicero? shall we sound him?
I think he will stand very strong with us.

speeches.speaker: CASCA
lines: Let us not leave him out.

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: No, by no means.

speeches.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
lines: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs
Will purchase us a good opinion
And buy men's voices to commend our deeds:
It shall be said, his judgment ruled our hands;
Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear,
But all be buried in his gravity.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: O, name him not: let us not break with him;
For he will never follow any thing
That other men begin.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Then leave him out.

speeches.speaker: CASCA
lines: Indeed he is not fit.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Decius, well urged: I think it is not meet,
Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar,
Should outlive Caesar: we shall find of him
A shrewd contriver; and, you know, his means,
If he improve them, may well stretch so far
As to annoy us all: which to prevent,
Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius,
To cut the head off and then hack the limbs,
Like wrath in death and envy afterwards;
For Antony is but a limb of Caesar:
Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius.
We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar;
And in the spirit of men there is no blood:
O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit,
And not dismember Caesar! But, alas,
Caesar must bleed for it! And, gentle friends,
Let's kill him boldly, but not wrathfully;
Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods,
Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds:
And let our hearts, as subtle masters do,
Stir up their servants to an act of rage,
And after seem to chide 'em. This shall make
Our purpose necessary and not envious:
Which so appearing to the common eyes,
We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers.
And for Mark Antony, think not of him;
For he can do no more than Caesar's arm
When Caesar's head is off.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Yet I fear him;
For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar--

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him:
If he love Caesar, all that he can do
Is to himself, take thought and die for Caesar:
And that were much he should; for he is given
To sports, to wildness and much company.

speeches.speaker: TREBONIUS
lines: There is no fear in him; let him not die;
For he will live, and laugh at this hereafter.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Peace! count the clock.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: The clock hath stricken three.

speeches.speaker: TREBONIUS
lines: 'Tis time to part.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: But it is doubtful yet,
Whether Caesar will come forth to-day, or no;
For he is superstitious grown of late,
Quite from the main opinion he held once
Of fantasy, of dreams and ceremonies:
It may be, these apparent prodigies,
The unaccustom'd terror of this night,
And the persuasion of his augurers,
May hold him from the Capitol to-day.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Never fear that: if he be so resolved,
I can o'ersway him; for he loves to hear
That unicorns may be betray'd with trees,
And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,
Lions with toils and men with flatterers;
But when I tell him he hates flatterers,
He says he does, being then most flattered.
Let me work;
For I can give his humour the true bent,
And I will bring him to the Capitol.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.

speeches.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
lines: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,
Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey:
I wonder none of you have thought of him.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Now, good Metellus, go along by him:
He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;
Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: The morning comes upon 's: we'll leave you, Brutus.
And, friends, disperse yourselves; but all remember
What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily;
Let not our looks put on our purposes,
But bear it as our Roman actors do,
With untired spirits and formal constancy:
And so good morrow to you every one.
Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter;
Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber:
Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,
Which busy care draws in the brains of men;
Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.

speeches.speaker: PORTIA
lines: Brutus, my lord!

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Portia, what mean you? wherefore rise you now?
It is not for your health thus to commit
Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.

speeches.speaker: PORTIA
lines: Nor for yours neither. You've ungently, Brutus,
Stole from my bed: and yesternight, at supper,
You suddenly arose, and walk'd about,
Musing and sighing, with your arms across,
And when I ask'd you what the matter was,
You stared upon me with ungentle looks;
I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head,
And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot;
Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not,
But, with an angry wafture of your hand,
Gave sign for me to leave you: so I did;
Fearing to strengthen that impatience
Which seem'd too much enkindled, and withal
Hoping it was but an effect of humour,
Which sometime hath his hour with every man.
It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep,
And could it work so much upon your shape
As it hath much prevail'd on your condition,
I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,
Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: I am not well in health, and that is all.

speeches.speaker: PORTIA
lines: Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health,
He would embrace the means to come by it.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.

speeches.speaker: PORTIA
lines: Is Brutus sick? and is it physical
To walk unbraced and suck up the humours
Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,
And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,
To dare the vile contagion of the night
And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air
To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus;
You have some sick offence within your mind,
Which, by the right and virtue of my place,
I ought to know of: and, upon my knees,
I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,
By all your vows of love and that great vow
Which did incorporate and make us one,
That you unfold to me, yourself, your half,
Why you are heavy, and what men to-night
Have had to resort to you: for here have been
Some six or seven, who did hide their faces
Even from darkness.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Kneel not, gentle Portia.

speeches.speaker: PORTIA
lines: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.
Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,
Is it excepted I should know no secrets
That appertain to you? Am I yourself
But, as it were, in sort or limitation,
To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,
And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs
Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,
Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: You are my true and honourable wife,
As dear to me as are the ruddy drops
That visit my sad heart

speeches.speaker: PORTIA
lines: If this were true, then should I know this secret.
I grant I am a woman; but withal
A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife:
I grant I am a woman; but withal
A woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.
Think you I am no stronger than my sex,
Being so father'd and so husbanded?
Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose 'em:
I have made strong proof of my constancy,
Giving myself a voluntary wound
Here, in the thigh: can I bear that with patience.
And not my husband's secrets?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: O ye gods,
Render me worthy of this noble wife!
Hark, hark! one knocks: Portia, go in awhile;
And by and by thy bosom shall partake
The secrets of my heart.
All my engagements I will construe to thee,
All the charactery of my sad brows:
Leave me with haste.
Lucius, who's that knocks?

speeches.speaker: LUCIUS
lines: He is a sick man that would speak with you.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of.
Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! how?

speeches.speaker: LIGARIUS
lines: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,
To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!

speeches.speaker: LIGARIUS
lines: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand
Any exploit worthy the name of honour.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,
Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

speeches.speaker: LIGARIUS
lines: By all the gods that Romans bow before,
I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome!
Brave son, derived from honourable loins!
Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up
My mortified spirit. Now bid me run,
And I will strive with things impossible;
Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

speeches.speaker: LIGARIUS
lines: But are not some whole that we must make sick?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: That must we also. What it is, my Caius,
I shall unfold to thee, as we are going
To whom it must be done.

speeches.speaker: LIGARIUS
lines: Set on your foot,
And with a heart new-fired I follow you,
To do I know not what: but it sufficeth
That Brutus leads me on.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Follow me, then.

scenes.name: SCENE II
scenes.title: CAESAR's house.
scenes.stageDirection: Thunder and lightning. Enter CAESAR, in his night-gown

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace to-night:
Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sleep cried out,
'Help, ho! they murder Caesar!' Who's within?

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: My lord?

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice
And bring me their opinions of success.

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: I will, my lord.

speeches.speaker: CALPURNIA
lines: What mean you, Caesar? think you to walk forth?
You shall not stir out of your house to-day.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me
Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see
The face of Caesar, they are vanished.

speeches.speaker: CALPURNIA
lines: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies,
Yet now they fright me. There is one within,
Besides the things that we have heard and seen,
Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
A lioness hath whelped in the streets;
And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead;
Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds,
In ranks and squadrons and right form of war,
Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol;
The noise of battle hurtled in the air,
Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,
And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.
O Caesar! these things are beyond all use,
And I do fear them.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: What can be avoided
Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
Yet Caesar shall go forth; for these predictions
Are to the world in general as to Caesar.

speeches.speaker: CALPURNIA
lines: When beggars die, there are no comets seen;
The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Cowards die many times before their deaths;
The valiant never taste of death but once.
Of all the wonders that I yet have heard.
It seems to me most strange that men should fear;
Seeing that death, a necessary end,
Will come when it will come.
What say the augurers?

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: They would not have you to stir forth to-day.
Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,
They could not find a heart within the beast.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: The gods do this in shame of cowardice:
Caesar should be a beast without a heart,
If he should stay at home to-day for fear.
No, Caesar shall not: danger knows full well
That Caesar is more dangerous than he:
We are two lions litter'd in one day,
And I the elder and more terrible:
And Caesar shall go forth.

speeches.speaker: CALPURNIA
lines: Alas, my lord,
Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.
Do not go forth to-day: call it my fear
That keeps you in the house, and not your own.
We'll send Mark Antony to the senate-house:
And he shall say you are not well to-day:
Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Mark Antony shall say I am not well,
And, for thy humour, I will stay at home.
Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Caesar, all hail! good morrow, worthy Caesar:
I come to fetch you to the senate-house.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: And you are come in very happy time,
To bear my greeting to the senators
And tell them that I will not come to-day:
Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser:
I will not come to-day: tell them so, Decius.

speeches.speaker: CALPURNIA
lines: Say he is sick.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Shall Caesar send a lie?
Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far,
To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,
Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: The cause is in my will: I will not come;
That is enough to satisfy the senate.
But for your private satisfaction,
Because I love you, I will let you know:
Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home:
She dreamt to-night she saw my statua,
Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,
Did run pure blood: and many lusty Romans
Came smiling, and did bathe their hands in it:
And these does she apply for warnings, and portents,
And evils imminent; and on her knee
Hath begg'd that I will stay at home to-day.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: This dream is all amiss interpreted;
It was a vision fair and fortunate:
Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,
In which so many smiling Romans bathed,
Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck
Reviving blood, and that great men shall press
For tinctures, stains, relics and cognizance.
This by Calpurnia's dream is signified.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: And this way have you well expounded it.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: I have, when you have heard what I can say:
And know it now: the senate have concluded
To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
If you shall send them word you will not come,
Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock
Apt to be render'd, for some one to say
'Break up the senate till another time,
When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.'
If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper
'Lo, Caesar is afraid'?
Pardon me, Caesar; for my dear dear love
To our proceeding bids me tell you this;
And reason to my love is liable.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calpurnia!
I am ashamed I did yield to them.
Give me my robe, for I will go.
And look where Publius is come to fetch me.
speeches.stagedir: Enter PUBLIUS, BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, and CINNA

speeches.speaker: PUBLIUS
lines: Good morrow, Caesar.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Welcome, Publius.
What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too?
Good morrow, Casca. Caius Ligarius,
Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy
As that same ague which hath made you lean.
What is 't o'clock?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
See! Antony, that revels long o' nights,
Is notwithstanding up. Good morrow, Antony.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: So to most noble Caesar.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Bid them prepare within:
I am to blame to be thus waited for.
Now, Cinna: now, Metellus: what, Trebonius!
I have an hour's talk in store for you;
Remember that you call on me to-day:
Be near me, that I may remember you.

speeches.speaker: TREBONIUS
lines: Caesar, I will:
and so near will I be,
That your best friends shall wish I had been further.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Good friends, go in, and taste some wine with me;
And we, like friends, will straightway go together.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: That every like is not the same, O Caesar,
The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon!

scenes.name: SCENE I
scenes.title: Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
scenes.stageDirection: Flourish. Enter CAESAR, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, METELLUS CIMBER, TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POPILIUS, PUBLIUS, and others

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: The ides of March are come.

speeches.speaker: Soothsayer
lines: Ay, Caesar; but not gone.

speeches.speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
lines: Hail, Caesar! read this schedule.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread,
At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

speeches.speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
lines: O Caesar, read mine first; for mine's a suit
That touches Caesar nearer: read it, great Caesar.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: What touches us ourself shall be last served.

speeches.speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
lines: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: What, is the fellow mad?

speeches.speaker: PUBLIUS
lines: Sirrah, give place.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: What, urge you your petitions in the street?
Come to the Capitol.

speeches.speaker: POPILIUS
lines: I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: What enterprise, Popilius?

speeches.speaker: POPILIUS
lines: Fare you well.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: What said Popilius Lena?

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: He wish'd to-day our enterprise might thrive.
I fear our purpose is discovered.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Look, how he makes to Caesar; mark him.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.
Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,
Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,
For I will slay myself.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Cassius, be constant:
Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes;
For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Trebonius knows his time; for, look you, Brutus.
He draws Mark Antony out of the way.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go,
And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: He is address'd: press near and second him.

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Are we all ready? What is now amiss
That Caesar and his senate must redress?

speeches.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
lines: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,
Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat
An humble heart,--

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: I must prevent thee, Cimber.
These couchings and these lowly courtesies
Might fire the blood of ordinary men,
And turn pre-ordinance and first decree
Into the law of children. Be not fond,
To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood
That will be thaw'd from the true quality
With that which melteth fools; I mean, sweet words,
Low-crooked court'sies and base spaniel-fawning.
Thy brother by decree is banished:
If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,
I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.
Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause
Will he be satisfied.

speeches.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
lines: Is there no voice more worthy than my own
To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear
For the repealing of my banish'd brother?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar;
Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may
Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: What, Brutus!

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon:
As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall,
To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: I could be well moved, if I were as you:
If I could pray to move, prayers would move me:
But I am constant as the northern star,
Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality
There is no fellow in the firmament.
The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks,
They are all fire and every one doth shine,
But there's but one in all doth hold his place:
So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men,
And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;
Yet in the number I do know but one
That unassailable holds on his rank,
Unshaked of motion: and that I am he,
Let me a little show it, even in this;
That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd,
And constant do remain to keep him so.

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: O Caesar,--

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: Great Caesar,--

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

speeches.speaker: CASCA
lines: Speak, hands for me!

speeches.speaker: CAESAR
lines: Et tu, Brute! Then fall, Caesar.

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!
Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Some to the common pulpits, and cry out
'Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!'

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: People and senators, be not affrighted;
Fly not; stand stiff: ambition's debt is paid.

speeches.speaker: CASCA
lines: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: And Cassius too.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Where's Publius?

speeches.speaker: CINNA
lines: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

speeches.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
lines: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's
Should chance--

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Talk not of standing. Publius, good cheer;
There is no harm intended to your person,
Nor to no Roman else: so tell them, Publius.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: And leave us, Publius; lest that the people,
Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Do so: and let no man abide this deed,
But we the doers.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Where is Antony?

speeches.speaker: TREBONIUS
lines: Fled to his house amazed:
Men, wives and children stare, cry out and run
As it were doomsday.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Fates, we will know your pleasures:
That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time
And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life
Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Grant that, and then is death a benefit:
So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridged
His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,
And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood
Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords:
Then walk we forth, even to the market-place,
And, waving our red weapons o'er our heads,
Let's all cry 'Peace, freedom and liberty!'

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Stoop, then, and wash. How many ages hence
Shall this our lofty scene be acted over
In states unborn and accents yet unknown!

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,
That now on Pompey's basis lies along
No worthier than the dust!

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: So oft as that shall be,
So often shall the knot of us be call'd
The men that gave their country liberty.

speeches.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines: What, shall we forth?

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Ay, every man away:
Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels
With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Soft! who comes here? A friend of Antony's.

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel:
Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down;
And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:
Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest;
Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving:
Say I love Brutus, and I honour him;
Say I fear'd Caesar, honour'd him and loved him.
If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony
May safely come to him, and be resolved
How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,
Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead
So well as Brutus living; but will follow
The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus
Thorough the hazards of this untrod state
With all true faith. So says my master Antony.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman;
I never thought him worse.
Tell him, so please him come unto this place,
He shall be satisfied; and, by my honour,
Depart untouch'd.

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: I'll fetch him presently.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: I wish we may: but yet have I a mind
That fears him much; and my misgiving still
Falls shrewdly to the purpose.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: But here comes Antony.
Welcome, Mark Antony.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: O mighty Caesar! dost thou lie so low?
Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,
Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.
I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,
Who else must be let blood, who else is rank:
If I myself, there is no hour so fit
As Caesar's death hour, nor no instrument
Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich
With the most noble blood of all this world.
I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,
Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,
Fulfil your pleasure. Live a thousand years,
I shall not find myself so apt to die:
No place will please me so, no mean of death,
As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,
The choice and master spirits of this age.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: O Antony, beg not your death of us.
Though now we must appear bloody and cruel,
As, by our hands and this our present act,
You see we do, yet see you but our hands
And this the bleeding business they have done:
Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful;
And pity to the general wrong of Rome--
As fire drives out fire, so pity pity--
Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,
To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony:
Our arms, in strength of malice, and our hearts
Of brothers' temper, do receive you in
With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's
In the disposing of new dignities.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Only be patient till we have appeased
The multitude, beside themselves with fear,
And then we will deliver you the cause,
Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,
Have thus proceeded.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: I doubt not of your wisdom.
Let each man render me his bloody hand:
First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you;
Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand;
Now, Decius Brutus, yours: now yours, Metellus;
Yours, Cinna; and, my valiant Casca, yours;
Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.
Gentlemen all,--alas, what shall I say?
My credit now stands on such slippery ground,
That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,
Either a coward or a flatterer.
That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true:
If then thy spirit look upon us now,
Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death,
To see thy thy Anthony making his peace,
Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes,
Most noble! in the presence of thy corse?
Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,
Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,
It would become me better than to close
In terms of friendship with thine enemies.
Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart;
Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,
Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy lethe.
O world, thou wast the forest to this hart;
And this, indeed, O world, the heart of thee.
How like a deer, strucken by many princes,
Dost thou here lie!

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Mark Antony,--

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Pardon me, Caius Cassius:
The enemies of Caesar shall say this;
Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: I blame you not for praising Caesar so;
But what compact mean you to have with us?
Will you be prick'd in number of our friends;
Or shall we on, and not depend on you?

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Therefore I took your hands, but was, indeed,
Sway'd from the point, by looking down on Caesar.
Friends am I with you all and love you all,
Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons
Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Or else were this a savage spectacle:
Our reasons are so full of good regard
That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,
You should be satisfied.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: That's all I seek:
And am moreover suitor that I may
Produce his body to the market-place;
And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,
Speak in the order of his funeral.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: You shall, Mark Antony.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: Brutus, a word with you.
You know not what you do: do not consent
That Antony speak in his funeral:
Know you how much the people may be moved
By that which he will utter?

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: By your pardon;
I will myself into the pulpit first,
And show the reason of our Caesar's death:
What Antony shall speak, I will protest
He speaks by leave and by permission,
And that we are contented Caesar shall
Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.
It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

speeches.speaker: CASSIUS
lines: I know not what may fall; I like it not.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.
You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,
But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,
And say you do't by our permission;
Else shall you not have any hand at all
About his funeral: and you shall speak
In the same pulpit whereto I am going,
After my speech is ended.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Be it so.
I do desire no more.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Prepare the body then, and follow us.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth,
That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!
Thou art the ruins of the noblest man
That ever lived in the tide of times.
Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Over thy wounds now do I prophesy,--
Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips,
To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue--
A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;
Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
Shall cumber all the parts of Italy;
Blood and destruction shall be so in use
And dreadful objects so familiar
That mothers shall but smile when they behold
Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war;
All pity choked with custom of fell deeds:
And Caesar's spirit, ranging for revenge,
With Ate by his side come hot from hell,
Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice
Cry  'Havoc,' and let slip the dogs of war;
That this foul deed shall smell above the earth
With carrion men, groaning for burial.
You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: I do, Mark Antony.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: He did receive his letters, and is coming;
And bid me say to you by word of mouth--
O Caesar!--

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Thy heart is big, get thee apart and weep.
Passion, I see, is catching; for mine eyes,
Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,
Began to water. Is thy master coming?

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: He lies to-night within seven leagues of Rome.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced:
Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,
No Rome of safety for Octavius yet;
Hie hence, and tell him so. Yet, stay awhile;
Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse
Into the market-place: there shall I try
In my oration, how the people take
The cruel issue of these bloody men;
According to the which, thou shalt discourse
To young Octavius of the state of things.
Lend me your hand.

scenes.name: SCENE II
scenes.title: Rome. The Forum.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS, and a throng of Citizens

speeches.speaker: Citizens
lines: We will be satisfied; let us be satisfied.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Then follow me, and give me audience, friends.
Cassius, go you into the other street,
And part the numbers.
Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here;
Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;
And public reasons shall be rendered
Of Caesar's death.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: I will hear Brutus speak.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: I will hear Cassius; and compare their reasons,
When severally we hear them rendered.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: The noble Brutus is ascended: silence!

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Be patient till the last.
Romans, countrymen, and lovers! hear me for my
cause, and be silent, that you may hear: believe me
for mine honour, and have respect to mine honour, that
you may believe: censure me in your wisdom, and
awake your senses, that you may the better judge.
If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of
Caesar's, to him I say, that Brutus' love to Caesar
was no less than his. If then that friend demand
why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer:
--Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved
Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living and
die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live
all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him;
as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was
valiant, I honour him: but, as he was ambitious, I
slew him. There is tears for his love; joy for his
fortune; honour for his valour; and death for his
ambition. Who is here so base that would be a
bondman? If any, speak; for him have I offended.
Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If
any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so
vile that will not love his country? If any, speak;
for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: None, Brutus, none.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Then none have I offended. I have done no more to
Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of
his death is enrolled in the Capitol; his glory not
extenuated, wherein he was worthy, nor his offences
enforced, for which he suffered death.
Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony: who,
though he had no hand in his death, shall receive
the benefit of his dying, a place in the
commonwealth; as which of you shall not? With this
I depart,--that, as I slew my best lover for the
good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself,
when it shall please my country to need my death.
speeches.stagedir: Enter ANTONY and others, with CAESAR's body

speeches.speaker: All
lines: Live, Brutus! live, live!

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Let him be Caesar.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Caesar's better parts
Shall be crown'd in Brutus.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: We'll bring him to his house
With shouts and clamours.

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: My countrymen,--

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Peace, ho!

speeches.speaker: BRUTUS
lines: Good countrymen, let me depart alone,
And, for my sake, stay here with Antony:
Do grace to Caesar's corpse, and grace his speech
Tending to Caesar's glories; which Mark Antony,
By our permission, is allow'd to make.
I do entreat you, not a man depart,
Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Stay, ho! and let us hear Mark Antony.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Let him go up into the public chair;
We'll hear him. Noble Antony, go up.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: What does he say of Brutus?

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: He says, for Brutus' sake,
He finds himself beholding to us all.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: This Caesar was a tyrant.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Nay, that's certain:
We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Peace! let us hear what Antony can say.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: You gentle Romans,--

speeches.speaker: Citizens
lines: Peace, ho! let us hear him.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears;
I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
The evil that men do lives after them;
The good is oft interred with their bones;
So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus
Hath told you Caesar was ambitious:
If it were so, it was a grievous fault,
And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it.
Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest--
For Brutus is an honourable man;
So are they all, all honourable men--
Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral.
He was my friend, faithful and just to me:
But Brutus says he was ambitious;
And Brutus is an honourable man.
He hath brought many captives home to Rome
Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill:
Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept:
Ambition should be made of sterner stuff:
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;
And Brutus is an honourable man.
You all did see that on the Lupercal
I thrice presented him a kingly crown,
Which he did thrice refuse: was this ambition?
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;
And, sure, he is an honourable man.
I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,
But here I am to speak what I do know.
You all did love him once, not without cause:
What cause withholds you then, to mourn for him?
O judgment! thou art fled to brutish beasts,
And men have lost their reason. Bear with me;
My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,
And I must pause till it come back to me.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: If thou consider rightly of the matter,
Caesar has had great wrong.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Has he, masters?
I fear there will a worse come in his place.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown;
Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Poor soul! his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Now mark him, he begins again to speak.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: But yesterday the word of Caesar might
Have stood against the world; now lies he there.
And none so poor to do him reverence.
O masters, if I were disposed to stir
Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,
I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong,
Who, you all know, are honourable men:
I will not do them wrong; I rather choose
To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you,
Than I will wrong such honourable men.
But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar;
I found it in his closet, 'tis his will:
Let but the commons hear this testament--
Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read--
And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds
And dip their napkins in his sacred blood,
Yea, beg a hair of him for memory,
And, dying, mention it within their wills,
Bequeathing it as a rich legacy
Unto their issue.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: We'll hear the will: read it, Mark Antony.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: The will, the will! we will hear Caesar's will.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Have patience, gentle friends, I must not read it;
It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.
You are not wood, you are not stones, but men;
And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar,
It will inflame you, it will make you mad:
'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs;
For, if you should, O, what would come of it!

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Read the will; we'll hear it, Antony;
You shall read us the will, Caesar's will.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Will you be patient? will you stay awhile?
I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it:
I fear I wrong the honourable men
Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: They were traitors: honourable men!

speeches.speaker: All
lines: The will! the testament!

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: They were villains, murderers: the will! read the will.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: You will compel me, then, to read the will?
Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar,
And let me show you him that made the will.
Shall I descend? and will you give me leave?

speeches.speaker: Several Citizens
lines: Come down.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Descend.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: You shall have leave.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: A ring; stand round.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Room for Antony, most noble Antony.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Nay, press not so upon me; stand far off.

speeches.speaker: Several Citizens
lines: Stand back; room; bear back.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
You all do know this mantle: I remember
The first time ever Caesar put it on;
'Twas on a summer's evening, in his tent,
That day he overcame the Nervii:
Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through:
See what a rent the envious Casca made:
Through this the well-beloved Brutus stabb'd;
And as he pluck'd his cursed steel away,
Mark how the blood of Caesar follow'd it,
As rushing out of doors, to be resolved
If Brutus so unkindly knock'd, or no;
For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel:
Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
This was the most unkindest cut of all;
For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,
Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms,
Quite vanquish'd him: then burst his mighty heart;
And, in his mantle muffling up his face,
Even at the base of Pompey's statua,
Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.
O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!
Then I, and you, and all of us fell down,
Whilst bloody treason flourish'd over us.
O, now you weep; and, I perceive, you feel
The dint of pity: these are gracious drops.
Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold
Our Caesar's vesture wounded? Look you here,
Here is himself, marr'd, as you see, with traitors.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: O piteous spectacle!

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: O noble Caesar!

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: O woful day!

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: O traitors, villains!

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: O most bloody sight!

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: We will be revenged.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay!
Let not a traitor live!

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Stay, countrymen.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Peace there! hear the noble Antony.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up
To such a sudden flood of mutiny.
They that have done this deed are honourable:
What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,
That made them do it: they are wise and honourable,
And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.
I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts:
I am no orator, as Brutus is;
But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man,
That love my friend; and that they know full well
That gave me public leave to speak of him:
For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth,
Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech,
To stir men's blood: I only speak right on;
I tell you that which you yourselves do know;
Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor poor dumb mouths,
And bid them speak for me: but were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony
Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue
In every wound of Caesar that should move
The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: We'll mutiny.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: We'll burn the house of Brutus.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Away, then! come, seek the conspirators.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: Peace, ho! Hear Antony. Most noble Antony!

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what:
Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
Alas, you know not: I must tell you then:
You have forgot the will I told you of.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: Most true. The will! Let's stay and hear the will.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.
To every Roman citizen he gives,
To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: O royal Caesar!

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Hear me with patience.

speeches.speaker: All
lines: Peace, ho!

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,
His private arbours and new-planted orchards,
On this side Tiber; he hath left them you,
And to your heirs for ever, common pleasures,
To walk abroad, and recreate yourselves.
Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Never, never. Come, away, away!
We'll burn his body in the holy place,
And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.
Take up the body.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Go fetch fire.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Pluck down benches.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Pluck down forms, windows, any thing.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot,
Take thou what course thou wilt!
How now, fellow!

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Where is he?

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: And thither will I straight to visit him:
He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will give us any thing.

speeches.speaker: Servant
lines: I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius
Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.

speeches.speaker: ANTONY
lines: Belike they had some notice of the people,
How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.

scenes.name: SCENE III
scenes.title: Rome. A street.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter CINNA the poet

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: I dreamt to-night that I did feast with Caesar,
And things unlucky charge my fantasy:
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
Yet something leads me forth.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: What is your name?

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Whither are you going?

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Where do you dwell?

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: Answer every man directly.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Ay, and briefly.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Ay, and wisely.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Ay, and truly, you were best.

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I
dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to
answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and
truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: That's as much as to say, they are fools that marry:
you'll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed; directly.

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: As a friend or an enemy?

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: As a friend.

speeches.speaker: Second Citizen
lines: That matter is answered directly.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: For your dwelling,--briefly.

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Your name, sir, truly.

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: Truly, my name is Cinna.

speeches.speaker: First Citizen
lines: Tear him to pieces; he's a conspirator.

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad verses.

speeches.speaker: CINNA THE POET
lines: I am not Cinna the conspirator.

speeches.speaker: Fourth Citizen
lines: It is no matter, his name's Cinna; pluck but his
name out of his heart, and turn him going.

speeches.speaker: Third Citizen
lines: Tear him, tear him! Come, brands ho! fire-brands:
to Brutus', to Cassius'; burn all: some to Decius'
house, and some to Casca's; some to Ligarius': away, go!

title: King Lear
synopsis: King divides kingdom, snubs daughter, goes mad, there's a storm, and everyone dies.
desc: King Lear is a tragedy written by William Shakespeare. It is based on the mythological Leir of Britain. King Lear relinquishes his power and land to two of his daughters. He becomes destitute and insane and a proscribed crux of political machinations.

title: Love's Labour's Lost
synopsis: Four men forswear women right before four women arrive to meet them; the men change their minds.
desc: Love's Labour's Lost follows the King of Navarre and his three companions as they attempt to swear off the company of women for three years in order to focus on study and fasting. Their subsequent infatuation with the Princess of France and her ladies makes them forsworn, (break their oath). In an untraditional ending for a comedy, the play closes with the death of the Princess's father, and all weddings are delayed for a year. The play draws on themes of masculine love and desire, reckoning and rationalisation, and reality versus fantasy.

title: Macbeth
synopsis: Macbeth hears that he is going to be king; he and Lady Macbeth kill people so he can become king; both of them die.
desc: Macbeth dramatises the damaging physical and psychological effects of political ambition on those who seek power for its own sake. Of all the plays that Shakespeare wrote during the reign of James I, who was patron of Shakespeare's acting company, Macbeth most clearly reflects the playwright's relationship with his sovereign.

persona.desc: Earl of Northumberland, General of the English Forces

scenes.name: SCENE I
scenes.title: An open Place. Thunder and Lightning
scenes.stageDirection: Enter three Witches

speeches.speaker: FIRST WITCH
lines: When shall we three meet again?
In thunder, lightning, or in rain?

speeches.speaker: SECOND WITCH
lines: When the hurlyburly's done,
When the battle's lost and won.

speeches.speaker: THIRD WITCH
lines: That will be ere the set of sun.

speeches.speaker: FIRST WITCH
lines: Where the place?

speeches.speaker: SECOND WITCH
lines: Upon the heath.

speeches.speaker: THIRD WITCH
lines: There to meet with Macbeth.

speeches.speaker: FIRST WITCH
lines: I come, Graymalkin!

speeches.speaker: ALL
lines: Paddock calls:--anon:--
Fair is foul, and foul is fair:
Hover through the fog and filthy air.

scenes.name: SCENE II
scenes.title: A Camp near Forres
scenes.stageDirection: Alarum within. Enter King Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Lennox, with Attendants, meeting a bleeding Soldier.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: What bloody man is that? He can report,
As seemeth by his plight, of the revolt
The newest state.

speeches.speaker: MALCOLM
lines: This is the sergeant
Who, like a good and hardy soldier, fought
'Gainst my captivity.--Hail, brave friend!
Say to the king the knowledge of the broil
As thou didst leave it.

speeches.speaker: SOLDIER
lines: Doubtful it stood;
As two spent swimmers that do cling together
And choke their art. The merciless Macdonwald,--
Worthy to be a rebel,--for to that
The multiplying villainies of nature
Do swarm upon him,--from the Western isles
Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied;
And fortune, on his damned quarrel smiling,
Show'd like a rebel's whore. But all's too weak;
For brave Macbeth,--well he deserves that name,--
Disdaining fortune, with his brandish'd steel,
Which smok'd with bloody execution,
Like valor's minion,
Carv'd out his passag tTill he fac'd the slave;
And ne'er shook hands, nor bade farewell to him,
Till he unseam'd him from the nave to the chaps,
And fix'd his head upon our battlements.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: O valiant cousin! worthy gentleman!

speeches.speaker: SOLDIER
lines: As whence the sun 'gins his reflection
Shipwrecking storms and direful thunders break;
So from that spring, whence comfort seem'd to come
Discomfort swells. Mark, King of Scotland, mark:
No sooner justice had, with valor arm'd,
Compell'd these skipping kerns to trust their heels,
But the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage,
With furbish'd arms and new supplies of men,
Began a fresh assault.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: Dismay'd not this
Our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?

speeches.speaker: SOLDIER
lines: Yes;
As sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.
If I say sooth, I must report they were
As cannons overcharg'd with double cracks;
So they
Doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe:
Except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds,
Or memorize another Golgotha,
I cannot tell:--
But I am faint; my gashes cry for help.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: So well thy words become thee as thy wounds;
They smack of honor both.--Go, get him surgeons.
Who comes here?

speeches.speaker: MALCOLM
lines: The worthy Thane of Ross.

speeches.speaker: LENNOX
lines: What a haste looks through his eyes! So should he look
That seems to speak things strange.

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: God save the King!

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: Whence cam'st thou, worthy thane?

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: From Fife, great king;
Where the Norweyan banners flout the sky
And fan our people cold.
Norway himself, with terrible numbers,
Assisted by that most disloyal traitor
The Thane of Cawdor, began a dismal conflict;
Till that Bellona's bridegroom, lapp'd in proof,
Confronted him with self-comparisons,
Point against point rebellious, arm 'gainst arm,
Curbing his lavish spirit: and, to conclude,
The victory fell on us.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: Great happiness!

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: That now
Sweno, the Norways' king, craves composition;
Nor would we deign him burial of his men
Till he disbursed, at Saint Colme's-inch,
Ten thousand dollars to our general use.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: No more that Thane of Cawdor shall deceive
Our bosom interest:--go pronounce his present death,
And with his former title greet Macbeth.

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: I'll see it done.

speeches.speaker: DUNCAN
lines: What he hath lost, noble Macbeth hath won.

scenes.name: SCENE I
scenes.title: Inverness. Court within the Castle.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter Banquo, preceeded by Fleance with a torch.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: How goes the night, boy?

speeches.speaker: FLEANCE
lines: The moon is down; I have not heard the clock.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: And she goes down at twelve.

speeches.speaker: FLEANCE
lines: I take't, 'tis later, sir.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: Hold, take my sword.--There's husbandry in heaven;
Their candles are all out:--take thee that too.--
A heavy summons lies like lead upon me,
And yet I would not sleep:--merciful powers,
Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that nature
Gives way to in repose!--Give me my sword.
Who's there?
speeches.stagedir: Enter Macbeth, and a Servant with a torch.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: A friend.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: What, sir, not yet at rest? The king's a-bed:
He hath been in unusual pleasure and
Sent forth great largess to your officers:
This diamond he greets your wife withal,
By the name of most kind hostess; and shut up
In measureless content.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: Being unprepar'd,
Our will became the servant to defect;
Which else should free have wrought.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: All's well.
I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters:
To you they have show'd some truth.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: I think not of them:
Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve,
We would spend it in some words upon that business,
If you would grant the time.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: At your kind'st leisure.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: If you shall cleave to my consent,--when 'tis,
It shall make honor for you.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: So I lose none
In seeking to augment it, but still keep
My bosom franchis'd, and allegiance clear,
I shall be counsell'd..

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: Good repose the while!

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: Thanks, sir: the like to you!

scenes.name: SCENE II
scenes.title: The same. Without the Castle.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter Ross and an old Man

speeches.speaker: OLD MAN
lines: Threescore and ten I can remember well:
Within the volume of which time I have seen
Hours dreadful and things strange; but this sore night
Hath trifled former knowings.

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: Ah, good father,
Thou seest, the heavens, as troubled with man's act,
Threaten his bloody stage: by the clock 'tis day,
And yet dark night strangles the travelling lamp;
Is't night's predominance, or the day's shame,
That darkness does the face of earth entomb,
When living light should kiss it?

speeches.speaker: OLD MAN
lines: 'Tis unnatural,
Even like the deed that's done. On Tuesday last,
A falcon, towering in her pride of place,
Was by a mousing owl hawk'd at and kill'd.

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: And Duncan's horses,--a thing most strange and certain,--
Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race,
Turn'd wild in nature, broke their stalls, flung out,
Contending 'gainst obedience, as they would make
War with mankind.

speeches.speaker: OLD MAN
lines: 'Tis said they eat each other.

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: They did so; to the amazement of mine eyes,
That look'd upon't.
Here comes the good Macduff.
How goes the world, sir, now?

speeches.speaker: MACDUFF
lines: Why, see you not?

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: Is't known who did this more than bloody deed?

speeches.speaker: MACDUFF
lines: Those that Macbeth hath slain.

speeches.speaker: ROSS
lines: Alas, the day!
What good could they pretend?

speeches.speaker: MACDUFF
lines: They were suborn'd:
Malcolm and Donalbain, the king's two sons,
Are stol'n away and fled; which puts upon them
Suspicion of the deed.

scenes.name: SCENE I
scenes.title: Forres. A Room in the Palace.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter Banquo

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: Thou hast it now,--king, Cawdor, Glamis, all,
As the weird women promis'd; and, I fear,
Thou play'dst most foully for't; yet it was said
It should not stand in thy posterity;
But that myself should be the root and father
Of many kings. If there come truth from them,--
As upon thee, Macbeth, their speeches shine,--
Why, by the verities on thee made good,
May they not be my oracles as well,
And set me up in hope? But hush; no more.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: Here's our chief guest.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: If he had been forgotten,
It had been as a gap in our great feast,
And all-thing unbecoming.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: To-night we hold a solemn supper, sir,
And I'll request your presence.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: Let your highness
Command upon me; to the which my duties
Are with a most indissoluble tie
For ever knit.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: Ride you this afternoon?

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: Ay, my good lord.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: We should have else desir'd your good advice,--
Which still hath been both grave and prosperous,--
In this day's council; but we'll take to-morrow.
Is't far you ride?

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: As far, my lord, as will fill up the time
'Twixt this and supper: go not my horse the better,
I must become a borrower of the night,
For a dark hour or twain.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: Fail not our feast.

speeches.speaker: BANQUO
lines: My lord, I will not.

scenes.name: SCENE II
scenes.title: The same. Another Room in the Palace.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter Lady Macbeth and a Servant.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: Is Banquo gone from court?

speeches.speaker: SERVANT
lines: Ay, madam, but returns again to-night.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: Say to the king, I would attend his leisure
For a few words.

speeches.speaker: SERVANT
lines: Madam, I will.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: Naught's had, all's spent,
Where our desire is got without content:
'Tis safer to be that which we destroy,
Than, by destruction, dwell in doubtful joy.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: We have scotch'd the snake, not kill'd it;
She'll close, and be herself; whilst our poor malice
Remains in danger of her former tooth.
But let the frame of things disjoint,
Both the worlds suffer
Ere we will eat our meal in fear, and sleep
In the affliction of these terrible dreams
That shake us nightly: better be with the dead,
Whom we, to gain our peace, have sent to peace,
Than on the torture of the mind to lie
In restless ecstasy. Duncan is in his grave;
After life's fitful fever he sleeps well;
Treason has done his worst: nor steel, nor poison,
Malice domestic, foreign levy, nothing,
Can touch him further.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: Come on;
Gentle my lord, sleek o'er your rugged looks;
Be bright and jovial among your guests to-night.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: So shall I, love; and so, I pray, be you:
Let your remembrance apply to Banquo;
Present him eminence, both with eye and tongue:
Unsafe the while, that we
Must lave our honours in these flattering streams,
And make our faces vizards to our hearts,
Disguising what they are.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: You must leave this.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: O, full of scorpions is my mind, dear wife!
Thou know'st that Banquo, and his Fleance, lives.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: But in them nature's copy's not eterne.

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: There's comfort yet; they are assailable;
Then be thou jocund: ere the bat hath flown
His cloister'd flight, ere to black Hecate's summons
The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums
Hath rung night's yawning peal, there shall be done
A deed of dreadful note.

speeches.speaker: LADY MACBETH
lines: What's to be done?

speeches.speaker: MACBETH
lines: Be innocent of the knowledge, dearest chuck,
Till thou applaud the deed. Come, seeling night,
Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful day;
And with thy bloody and invisible hand
Cancel and tear to pieces that great bond
Which keeps me pale! Light thickens; and the crow
Makes wing to the rooky wood:
Good things of day begin to droop and drowse;
While night's black agents to their preys do rouse.
Thou marvell'st at my words: but hold thee still;
Things bad begun make strong themselves by ill.
So, prithee, go with me.

title: The Merry Wives of Windsor
synopsis: Falstaff tries to pursue two married women; the women are smart; they put him in a river, dress him as a woman, and bring him to a haunted forest; everyone is happy.
desc: The Merry Wives of Windsor is a comedy by William Shakespeare first published in 1602, though believed to have been written in or before 1597. The Windsor of the play's title is a reference to the town of Windsor, also the location of Windsor Castle, in Berkshire, England. Though nominally set in the reign of Henry IV or early in the reign of Henry V, the play makes no pretence to exist outside contemporary Elizabethan era English middle class life. It features the character Sir John Falstaff, the fat knight who had previously been featured in Henry IV, Part 1 and Part 2. It has been adapted for the opera at least ten times. The play is one of Shakespeare's lesser-regarded works among literary critics. Tradition has it that The Merry Wives of Windsor was written at the request of Queen Elizabeth I.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
synopsis: People get lost in the woods. Puck manipulates their romantic affections and (in one case) anatomical head-shape. They put on a play.
desc: The play is set in Athens, and consists of several subplots that revolve around the marriage of Theseus and Hippolyta. One subplot involves a conflict among four Athenian lovers. Another follows a group of six amateur actors rehearsing the play which they are to perform before the wedding. Both groups find themselves in a forest inhabited by fairies who manipulate the humans and are engaged in their own domestic intrigue. The play is one of Shakespeare's most popular and is widely performed.

persona.desc: master of the revels to Theseus
queen of the Amazons, betrothed to Theseus
daughter to Egeus, in love with Lysander

scenes.name: SCENE I
scenes.title: Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour
Draws on apace; four happy days bring in
Another moon: but, O, methinks, how slow
This old moon wanes! she lingers my desires,
Like to a step-dame or a dowager
Long withering out a young man revenue.

speeches.speaker: HIPPOLYTA
lines: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;
Four nights will quickly dream away the time;
And then the moon, like to a silver bow
New-bent in heaven, shall behold the night
Of our solemnities.

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: Go, Philostrate,
Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments;
Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;
Turn melancholy forth to funerals;
The pale companion is not for our pomp.
Hippolyta, I woo'd thee with my sword,
And won thy love, doing thee injuries;
But I will wed thee in another key,
With pomp, with triumph and with revelling.

speeches.speaker: EGEUS
lines: Happy be Theseus, our renowned duke!

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: Thanks, good Egeus: what's the news with thee?

speeches.speaker: EGEUS
lines: Full of vexation come I, with complaint
Against my child, my daughter Hermia.
Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord,
This man hath my consent to marry her.
Stand forth, Lysander: and my gracious duke,
This man hath bewitch'd the bosom of my child;
Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,
And interchanged love-tokens with my child:
Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,
With feigning voice verses of feigning love,
And stolen the impression of her fantasy
With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gawds, conceits,
Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats, messengers
Of strong prevailment in unharden'd youth:
With cunning hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart,
Turn'd her obedience, which is due to me,
To stubborn harshness: and, my gracious duke,
Be it so she; will not here before your grace
Consent to marry with Demetrius,
I beg the ancient privilege of Athens,
As she is mine, I may dispose of her:
Which shall be either to this gentleman
Or to her death, according to our law
Immediately provided in that case.

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: What say you, Hermia? be advised fair maid:
To you your father should be as a god;
One that composed your beauties, yea, and one
To whom you are but as a form in wax
By him imprinted and within his power
To leave the figure or disfigure it.
Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.

speeches.speaker: HERMIA
lines: So is Lysander.

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: In himself he is;
But in this kind, wanting your father's voice,
The other must be held the worthier.

speeches.speaker: HERMIA
lines: I would my father look'd but with my eyes.

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

speeches.speaker: HERMIA
lines: I do entreat your grace to pardon me.
I know not by what power I am made bold,
Nor how it may concern my modesty,
In such a presence here to plead my thoughts;
But I beseech your grace that I may know
The worst that may befall me in this case,
If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: Either to die the death or to abjure
For ever the society of men.
Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires;
Know of your youth, examine well your blood,
Whether, if you yield not to your father's choice,
You can endure the livery of a nun,
For aye to be in shady cloister mew'd,
To live a barren sister all your life,
Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitless moon.
Thrice-blessed they that master so their blood,
To undergo such maiden pilgrimage;
But earthlier happy is the rose distill'd,
Than that which withering on the virgin thorn
Grows, lives and dies in single blessedness.

speeches.speaker: HERMIA
lines: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,
Ere I will my virgin patent up
Unto his lordship, whose unwished yoke
My soul consents not to give sovereignty.

speeches.speaker: THESEUS
lines: Take time to pause; and, by the nest new moon--
The sealing-day betwixt my love and me,
For everlasting bond of fellowship--
Upon that day either prepare to die
For disobedience to your father's will,
Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would;
Or on Diana's altar to protest
For aye austerity and single life.

speeches.speaker: DEMETRIUS
lines: Relent, sweet Hermia: and, Lysander, yield
Thy crazed title to my certain right.

speeches.speaker: LYSANDER
lines: You have her father's love, Demetrius;
Let me have Hermia's: do you marry him.

speeches.speaker: EGEUS
lines: Scornful Lysander! true, he hath my love,
And what is mine my love shall render him.
And she is mine, and all my right of her
I do estate unto Demetrius.

speeches.speaker: LYSANDER
lines: I am, my lord, as well derived as he,
As well possess'd; my love is more than his;
My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd,
If not with vantage, as Demetrius';
And, which is more than all these boasts can be,
I am beloved of beauteous Hermia:
Why should not I then prosecute my right?
Demetrius, I'll avouch it to his head,
Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena,
And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes,
Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry,
Upon this spotted and inconstant man.

scenes.name: SCENE II
scenes.title: Athens. QUINCE'S house.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Is all our company here?

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: You were best to call them generally, man by man,
according to the scrip.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is
thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our
interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his
wedding-day at night.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats
on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow
to a point.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Marry, our play is, The most lamentable comedy, and
most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a
merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your
actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: What is Pyramus? a lover, or a tyrant?

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: A lover, that kills himself most gallant for love.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: That will ask some tears in the true performing of
it: if I do it, let the audience look to their
eyes; I will move storms, I will condole in some
measure. To the rest: yet my chief humour is for a
tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to
tear a cat in, to make all split.
The raging rocks
And shivering shocks
Shall break the locks
Of prison gates;
And Phibbus' car
Shall shine from far
And make and mar
The foolish Fates.
This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players.
This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein; a lover is
more condoling.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

speeches.speaker: FLUTE
lines: Here, Peter Quince.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Flute, you must take Thisby on you.

speeches.speaker: FLUTE
lines: What is Thisby? a wandering knight?

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

speeches.speaker: FLUTE
lines: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman; I have a beard coming.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: That's all one: you shall play it in a mask, and
you may speak as small as you will.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby too, I'll
speak in a monstrous little voice. 'Thisne,
Thisne;' 'Ah, Pyramus, lover dear! thy Thisby dear,
and lady dear!'

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: No, no; you must play Pyramus: and, Flute, you Thisby.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: Well, proceed.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

speeches.speaker: STARVELING
lines: Here, Peter Quince.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother.
Tom Snout, the tinker.

speeches.speaker: SNOUT
lines: Here, Peter Quince.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: You, Pyramus' father: myself, Thisby's father:
Snug, the joiner; you, the lion's part: and, I
hope, here is a play fitted.

speeches.speaker: SNUG
lines: Have you the lion's part written? pray you, if it
be, give it me, for I am slow of study.

speeches.speaker: QUINCE
lines: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

speeches.speaker: BOTTOM
lines: Let me play the lion too: I will roar, that I will
do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar,
that I will make the duke say 'Let him roar again,
let him roar again.'

scenes.name: SCENE I
scenes.title: A wood near Athens.
scenes.stageDirection: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
